Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Competition and cooperation in the honey bee gut microbiota
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pollinator health is important for both agricultural and natural ecosystems, and one of the most important pollinators, especially in agriculture, is the honey bee. In this project, researchers will focus on bacteria in honey bee guts, because gut bacteria affect animals' health. They will study how these bacteria interact with one another, because this is important for how stable helpful gut bacterial communities are, and how they interact with the host animal. The researchers will continue working with two critical bacteria in the bee gut. They have already shown how these bacteria have toxins with which they can attack one another. However, it is likely that these bacteria also help one another in some situations. The researchers will use recently developed methods to look at whether and how these bacteria pass nutrients to one another and to the host bee. This will contribute to understanding how bee-gut bacterial communities stay stable through time. It will help to develop new routes to improving bee health. In addition, during the project graduate and undergraduate researchers will be trained in state-of-the-art methods in microbiology.

As insects can take up and utilize byproducts of carbohydrate fermentation, honeybees may benefit from the metabolic activities of members of their gut microbial communities through both the degradation of toxic sugars and the production of useful byproducts. To better understand the role of cooperative metabolic interactions in gut communities, this project will trace nutrient exchange in the honeybee gut. Genomic evidence suggests that the bee gut microbes Snodgrassella alvi and Gilliamella apicola depend upon one another for production of nutrients. G. apicola metabolizes carbohydrates that S. alvi cannot, and metabolizes sugars found in nectar that are toxic to honey bees. This project will use isotopically-labeled monosaccharides that can be utilized by G. apicola, but not by S. alvi or the host, to trace metabolic interactions in the bee gut. DNA-stable isotope probing (DNA-SIP) will be used to track incorporation of labeled carbon atoms into bacterial DNA, while incorporation of these atoms into host tissues will be measured through elemental analysis and isotope ratio mass spectrometry. This research will contribute to a greater fundamental understanding of the processes that govern cooperative metabolic interactions among members of the gut microbiota and between the microbiota and the host, and will demonstrate the important potential role of SIP methods in hypothesis testing in microbial community ecology, a framework in which it is uncommonly used.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Complex assemblages of microbes are found in the guts of animals. Cooperative and competitive interactions between bacteria are likely to play a role in the resilience of these communities. Western honey bee guts contain a relatively simple bacterial community comprised of a small number of species found only in honey bees and closely related bee species. The simplicity and experimental tractability of the resident microbiota makes the bee gut a useful model system for studying interactions between coevolved bacteria.

We determined that a high proportion of bee gut microbes encode type VI secretion systems (T6SSs), which are protein complexes used in interbacterial competition to deliver toxins into nearby cells. Core bee gut taxa, including co-localized species Snodgrassella alvi and Gilliamella apicola, have retained T6SSs over millions of years of host and bacterial diversification, while accumulating diverse pools of T6SS-associated toxins. These T6SSs may contribute to the stability of the community by ensuring that only coevolved strains with immunity to each other’s secreted toxins can co-colonize the gut. This may affect host health by excluding environmental bacteria and preserving functions of the native community, such as conversion of indigestible dietary compounds into molecules that can be used by the host for energy.

To better understand the importance of the native bee gut microbiota to host health, we used elemental analysis/isotope ratio mass spectrometry (EA/IRMS) to examine uptake of the toxic sugar mannose by honey bees lacking their natural gut microbiota, colonized with a conventional gut community, or colonized with only S. alvi. We found that bees with a conventional gut microbiota had increased appetite relative to microbiota-free bees, consistent with previous reports. Furthermore, our results suggest that a single strain of S. alvi, which does not metabolize mannose to acetate, can increase appetite as much as the full community and may increase mannose transport out of the gut, increasing host exposure to the toxic sugar.

This work expands our understanding of the importance of the bee gut microbiota in affecting host exposure to and energy acquisition from a dietary sugar that is indigestible and toxic to bees if not metabolized by gut bacteria. Additionally, results from this project suggest that the functions of stimulating host appetite and degrading indigestible dietary compounds may be divided between different gut taxa. These findings emphasize the importance of the stability of gut community composition for host health and identify new avenues of experimental inquiry into the role of the microbiota in bee nutrition.

Honey bees are important pollinators, whose wellbeing is important for both agriculture and ecosystems. This study contributes to our understanding of the importance of the gut microbiota for honey bee health. Additionally, this work created opportunities for two undergraduate students at the University of Texas at Austin to participate in research.
